Deidentified_paragraph_text: The new conventional wisdom is pessimistic homelessness is an intractable feature of the urban landscape. Political leaders have abandoned any pretension of abolishing homelessness, focusing instead on strategies of containment and harm reduction. But this outlook, too, is wrong. [PERSON] is neither intractable nor permanent, and policies of harm reduction have shown little capacity to reduce it. Rather than continue down this path, [ORGANIZATION] officials should learn from cities that have embraced a different modelcompassionate enforcementthat has demonstrated significant success over [ORGANIZATION]. Though [ORGANIZATION] cities have dominated the headlines with bad news, cities such as [ORGANIZATION], which has reduced homelessness by more than 50 percent since [LOCATION], show that another [STREET] is possible.

Deidentified_article_title: "Compassionate Enforcement"
Deidentified_paragraph_text: Various misconceptions have kept major cities from reducing homelessness. A prevailing view holds that homelessness is a national problem many service providers, local officials, and state governors have insisted that the federal government is responsible for solving it. This contention serves the dual purpose of shifting blame to [ORGANIZATION] and obscuring the failure of the political class in [ORGANIZATION] cities, but it is false. DATE0, homelessness decreased 10 percent nationwide moreover, on a geographic basis, homelessness declined in 40 out of 50 states. The reality is that homelessness is not distributed evenly across the country. It has become more concentrated in a handful of states, particularly [PERSON], [ORGANIZATION], and [ORGANIZATION], which now account for one-third of the nations homeless population.

Deidentified_article_title: "Compassionate Enforcement"
Deidentified_paragraph_text: Why? Activists and political leaders commonly point to weather and rising rents. Though its obviously easier to live on the streets in [ORGANIZATION] than in [ORGANIZATION] during [ORGANIZATION], weather alone does not explain the distribution of homelessness in GPE2. As [ORGANIZATION] has shown, the rate of homelessness is high in [LOCATION] cities but low in GPE4 cities, which also have warm [LOCATION] climates. Overall, according to ORG1 analysis, unsheltered homelessness is two to four times higher than predicted when accounting for weather in [LOCATION], [PERSON], and [ORGANIZATION], and lower than predicted when accounting for weather in [ORGANIZATION], GPE9, and [ORGANIZATION]0.

Deidentified_article_title: "Compassionate Enforcement"
Deidentified_paragraph_text: The more deeply entrenched argument is that homelessness is a housing problem. Progressive leaders in [ORGANIZATION] cities have convinced the public that rising rents cause homelessness. There is a beguiling simplicity to this narrative marginalized people are living paycheck to paycheck, the rent goes upand theyre thrown onto the streets. The officials often cite in support of this claim a [ORGANIZATION] report that purports to show that rising rents mean a larger homeless population. In the reports headline, the researchers find a strong correlation between increases in rental prices and homelessness in [ORGANIZATION], [PERSON], [ORGANIZATION], [PERSON], and [PERSON], buried in the same report, the research shows that homelessness remained flat or decreased, despite rising rents, in [LOCATION], GPE6, GPE7, GPE8, GPE9, [PERSON]0, [PERSON]1, [PERSON]2, [PERSON]3, [PERSON]4, [PERSON]5, [PERSON]6, [PERSON]7, [PERSON]8, [PERSON]9, [ORGANIZATION]0, [ORGANIZATION]1, [ORGANIZATION]2, [ORGANIZATION]3, and [ORGANIZATION]4. Put another [STREET], rising rents and homelessness are correlated in five of the top 25 metros but not correlated in 20 of the top 25 metrosundermining the conclusion that rising rents cause homelessness.

Deidentified_article_title: "Compassionate Enforcement"
Deidentified_paragraph_text: To avoid misunderstanding, lets concede this much it is certainly true that weather and housing prices have some effect on homelessness. Warm weather allows for [ORGANIZATION] unsheltered living, and expensive real-estate markets raise the economic floor for avoiding homelessnessits much easier to maintain housing where the rent is [DATE], not 3,000. But these explanations go only so far.

Deidentified_article_title: "Compassionate Enforcement"
Deidentified_paragraph_text: Public policy is a better explanation for the current distribution of homelessness in [ORGANIZATION]. Researchers mostly have analyzed homelessness according to middle-class norms, believing that the homeless respond primarily to measures of poverty, rental prices, and housing policy. That overlooks an important distinction the homeless have a different set of incentives from the average citizen. Their world is not like that of the middle class. The facts, which have become taboo in progressive cities, are simple 75 percent of the unsheltered homeless have a serious addiction, 78 percent have a mental illness, and, as a group, they are nearly 100 times more likely to commit crimes and get booked into jail than the typical citizen. Theirs is a world of tangled pathologies, driven by the economics of the drug trade, the psychology of addiction, and the culture of transient encampments.

Deidentified_article_title: "Compassionate Enforcement"
Deidentified_paragraph_text: And yet, notwithstanding their high rates of addiction and mental illness, the homeless are essentially rational actors in the sense that, on their own terms, they respond to economic, policy, and cultural incentives. Consider one situation that illustrates the larger point.

Deidentified_article_title: "Compassionate Enforcement"
Deidentified_paragraph_text: [ORGANIZATION] has effectively decriminalized public camping and drug consumption [ORGANIZATION] enforces the law against them. After two [ORGANIZATION] city councilmen complained in the [ORGANIZATION] Times that [ORGANIZATION] was pushing its homeless into [ORGANIZATION], then[ORGANIZATION] mayor PERSON0 shot back in a letter to the editor The encampment under FAC0 on FAC1 . . . has been the scene of numerous violent crimes. The [ORGANIZATION] [INSTITUTION] does not check in with the homeless people living there nearly as often as [ORGANIZATION] police do. If I was a homeless person inclined to do drugs and commit crimes, I would feel safer in [ORGANIZATION] than [ORGANIZATION], whose police are there to protect all residents.

Deidentified_article_title: "Compassionate Enforcement"
Deidentified_paragraph_text: The FAC0 experiment provides a useful framework for reexamining the geography of homelessness. In [ORGANIZATION], the data are consistent with the enforcement principle across the state, the homeless gravitate to the most permissive policy environments. In [ORGANIZATION], 35 percent of the homeless migrated to the county after becoming homeless elsewhere, including 19 percent who came from another state. In [ORGANIZATION], 30 percent of the homeless came to the county after becoming homeless elsewhere, plus an additional 6 percent who became homeless after living in GPE3 for [ORGANIZATION]. [ORGANIZATION] estimates that 450 chronically homeless individuals migrate to the city [LOCATION] because of the perception that it is a sanctuary for people who are unwilling to participate in programs designed to get them off, and keep them off, a life in the streets.

Deidentified_article_title: "Compassionate Enforcement"
Deidentified_paragraph_text: In [ORGANIZATION], the numbers from the [ORGANIZATION] metropolitan area provide more evidence for the enforcement hypothesis. According to data from the City of [ORGANIZATION], an astonishing 51 percent of the homeless migrated to the city after becoming homeless somewhere else. By the conventional wisdoms middle-class logic, this would be an irrational choice an individual with no shelter or stable source of income would not move to one of the nations most expensive cities. But again, the homeless operate under a different set of assumptions and incentives. They are strongly motivated to move to the most permissive environment. In a research survey of homeless migrants to [ORGANIZATION], 15 percent said that they came to access homeless services, 10 percent came for legal marijuana, and 16 percent were transients who were traveling or visiting when they decided to set up camp. These responses may obscure the largest incentive of all the de facto legalization of [STREET] camping, drug consumption, and property crime. As former [ORGANIZATION] public safety advisor [ORGANIZATION] has shown, the city is now home to a large population of homeless prolific offenders who commit property crimes to feed their addictionsand are rarely held to account by the criminal-justice system.

Deidentified_article_title: "Compassionate Enforcement"
Deidentified_paragraph_text: Some critics will dismiss these conclusions as an endorsement of an enforcement-only approach that criminalizes [PERSON] But the lesson is not that cities should withhold help from the homeless its that cities must balance the provision of public services with the maintenance of public order. Cities that fail to acknowledge the relationship between permissiveness, migration, and rates of homelessness will not make progress.

Deidentified_article_title: "Compassionate Enforcement"
Deidentified_paragraph_text: [ORGANIZATION] is perhaps the American city that best demonstrates the power of compassionate enforcement. Its GPE1 is a moderate district, with conservative suburban areas and a liberal urban core. [ORGANIZATION]s mayor, [ORGANIZATION], is a Democrat, but his rhetoric on homelessness is very different from that heard in GPE2, [PERSON], and [PERSON]. It is simply not acceptable for people to live on the streets it is not good for them, and it is not good for the city, [ORGANIZATION] has declared. We will tackle this complicated issue, and we will do it humanely with a meaningful approach that balances the needs of the homeless and the concerns of neighborhoods they impact.

Deidentified_article_title: "Compassionate Enforcement"
Deidentified_paragraph_text: [ORGANIZATION]s policy exemplifies what [ORGANIZATION] calls a tough love approach. The city has built permanent supportive housing for the chronically homeless, cobbled together a coalition of nonprofit partners, and lobbied the state government for more mental-health and addiction services. At the same time, [ORGANIZATION] has enforced a strict ban on public camping and proposed a citywide campaign to discourage citizens from giving money to panhandlers. The [ORGANIZATION] sheriffs homeless-outreach team attempts to connect the homeless with services but also enforces the law. The sheriffs office acknowledges that mental illness and substance abuse are common in the homeless population and recognizes that it must maintain order in residential neighborhoods. The team shuts down tent cities and conducts regular cleanups, discouraging the permanent encampment culture seen in [ORGANIZATION] cities. The results have been stunning [ORGANIZATION], [ORGANIZATION] reduced its homeless population by 54 percent.

Deidentified_article_title: "Compassionate Enforcement"
Deidentified_paragraph_text: These outcomes lay waste to the conventional wisdom. [ORGANIZATION] has warmer [ORGANIZATION] than [ORGANIZATION], GPE2, [PERSON], and GPE4. During DATE1 that [ORGANIZATION] reduced homelessness by more than half, the average rent for a one-bedroom apartment rose by 54 percent. Clearly, neither the weather nor housing prices can explain the outcomes in [ORGANIZATION].

Deidentified_article_title: "Compassionate Enforcement"
Deidentified_paragraph_text: Some analysts have suggested that [PERSON]s approach worked because the city built permanent supportive housing, created a coalition of partners, and implemented advanced data-tracking. But every major [ORGANIZATION] city has done these things. [ORGANIZATION], [PERSON], and [ORGANIZATION] have also spent billions on permanent supportive housing and subsidized apartments, hosted conferences and working groups to increase coordination, and implemented the same [ORGANIZATION] as [PERSON]. And yet, over the same period, homelessness increased 15 percent in [ORGANIZATION], 24 percent in [PERSON], and 25 percent in [ORGANIZATION]. If these interventions worked in [PERSON], why didnt they work elsewhere?

Deidentified_article_title: "Compassionate Enforcement"
Deidentified_paragraph_text: The truth is straightforward. [ORGANIZATION] achieved different results because, in addition to these supportive policies, it also enforced the law. Unlike the [ORGANIZATION] cities, [ORGANIZATION] did not enable and encourage the worst aspects of [STREET] homelessness. Where a [ORGANIZATION] politician opposes hosing down feces-covered sidewalks because hoses supposedly have racist connotations, [ORGANIZATION] fights in the courts for the right to clean up encampments. Where GPE2 leaders push for supervised injection sites and decriminalizing thefts under 950, [ORGANIZATION] pushes for tighter restrictions on aggressive panhandling, windshield washing, and other street obstructions.

Deidentified_article_title: "Compassionate Enforcement"
Deidentified_paragraph_text: [ORGANIZATION]s theory helps illustrate why progressive cities have been unable to reduce homelessness, despite billions in public spending. Progressives, according to [ORGANIZATION], have an unconstrained vision of the world and an optimistic view of human nature and of human perfectibility. They tend to believe that the homeless are victims of circumstance and inequality and simply need a helping hand to improve their lives.

Deidentified_article_title: "Compassionate Enforcement"
Deidentified_paragraph_text: This understanding has three moral blind spots. First, because progressives discount the moral foundation of authority, they dismiss worries about crime, disorder, and violence when thinking about homelessness and generally are skeptical about the need for law enforcement. [ORGANIZATION] progressives have sought to decriminalize public camping, drug consumption, and property crimes because they view authority as the problem, not part of the solution. Second, because progressives discount the moral foundation of purity, they overlook and excuse the filth associated with [STREET] camping. Homeless encampments have proved to be havens for trash, needles, drugs, human waste, and infectious diseases, yet [ORGANIZATION] progressives have fought to stop the sweeps of tent cities and filed lawsuits against encampment cleanups. They prioritize care for our curbside neighbors over sanitation, cleanliness, and public-health concerns. Third, because progressives discount in-group loyalty, they do not see a significant homeless influx as a problem. They tend to make no distinction between the local and nonlocal homeless population and reject concerns about cities becoming magnets for homeless migrants as xenophobic and homeless-hating. Put simply, progressive cities have adopted a philosophy of all compassion and no enforcement that creates a cycle of permissiveness, enablement, and disorder.

Deidentified_article_title: "Compassionate Enforcement"
Deidentified_paragraph_text: Critics might deny that the progressive approach is extreme, pointing to outreach teams as examples of authority, sanitation plans as examples of purity, and bus programs as examples of in-group loyalty. But at the practical level, the homeless-services apparatus has become one of the most ideologically radical sectors of [ORGANIZATION] government. In [ORGANIZATION], the regional homelessness authority recently held its DATE0 conference on the theme Decolonizing Our Collective Work, with sessions designed to interrogate the current structures of power and examine the legacies of structural racism in our systems, and co-design a path towards liberation with black, indigenous, brown and other marginalized communities. As part of the conference, the agency hired transgender stripper [ORGANIZATION] to perform a drag show, give lap dances, and kiss attendees. What does any of this have to do with reducing homelessness? Nothing. Its about repeating the nostrums of social justice, radicalizing homeless-services providers, and advancing the larger progressive political project. Of course, these agencies have failed to reduce homelessness any entity that prioritizes decolonizing our collective work over actually improving things is doomed to fail.

Deidentified_article_title: "Compassionate Enforcement"
Deidentified_paragraph_text: Policies can change quickly, but ideologies have deeper roots. In the near term, there will likely be a continued redistribution of homelessness toward the warmest, most expensive, and most permissive cities, focused primarily on the coastal enclaves of [ORGANIZATION], [PERSON], and [ORGANIZATION]. [ORGANIZATION] cities have recently announced unprecedented multibillion-dollar expenditures on homelessness, but money alone cannot overcome deficient political cultures that have proved unable to cope with the dark side of homelessness addiction, crime, violence, squalor, and disease. If the homeless-services apparatus continues to prioritize political convictions over practical plans, it will waste billions on programs that fail to address the need for both compassion and enforcement.

Deidentified_article_title: "Compassionate Enforcement"
Deidentified_paragraph_text: The crisis presents an opportunity, however, for cities willing to try a different approach. As [ORGANIZATION] has demonstrated, local leaders can meaningfully reduce homelessness through a strategy of tough loveleading with the provision of shelter and services but maintaining public order through outreach, cleanups, and enforcement of anti-camping laws. Some progressive leaders have complained that enforcement policies shift the burden of homelessness onto the largest cities. But [ORGANIZATION] is the nations fourth-largest city. And cities already compete on taxes, infrastructure, amenities, and various other policy choiceswhy should homeless policy not be among them? Small and medium-size cities should not lower their standards of public order rather, it is incumbent upon neighboring cities to reduce the magnet effect of their own permissive policies.

Deidentified_article_title: "Compassionate Enforcement"
Deidentified_paragraph_text: In the long term, it would be best for all cities to adopt compassionate enforcement. If cities can close down negative pathwayspublic encampments, open drug consumption, and uncontrolled property crimesthey will be able to redirect the homeless toward better outcomes. In cities such as [ORGANIZATION], [PERSON], and [ORGANIZATION], political leaders must reorient their policies and think more broadly about the moral dimension of homelessness.

Deidentified_article_title: "Compassionate Enforcement"
Deidentified_paragraph_text: More than 180,000 people live on the streets of [ORGANIZATION] cities. Their fate depends, in part, on policymakers. Ultimately, compassion should be measured not by good intentions but by outcomes. If progressive leaders want to live up to their own values, they must demonstrate results on homelessness. [ORGANIZATION] provides a model of how to do so.

Deidentified_article_title: "Subsidizing Addiction"
Deidentified_paragraph_text: [ORGANIZATION], an older, soft-spoken homeless man, recently went to [ORGANIZATION] to see if he was eligible for free housing. One of my friends, a fellow researcher, accompanied him.

Deidentified_article_title: "Subsidizing Addiction"
Deidentified_paragraph_text: DATE0, drug abuse is not a barrier for homeless people seeking housing and welfare. In fact, many policies make drug abuse a prerequisite for services. Federal, state, and local programs give addicts more funds and assistance than nonaddicts. And other favors go to homeless individuals who can prove that theyre engaging in criminal activity.

Deidentified_article_title: "Subsidizing Addiction"
Deidentified_paragraph_text: Most Americans recognize that subsidizing drug abuse and crime is a terrible idea. In [ORGANIZATION], the public forced [ORGANIZATION] to end similar, older programs. But the bureaucracy and the advocates have found ways to resurrect such policiesand expand them. For many welfare programs DATE1, the deserving recipients are no longer those with the most setbacks or the least income but those maintaining the worst addictions and committing the most crimes. If anyone wonders why, say, [ORGANIZATION] suffers around 2,000 homeless deaths a yearquadruple the level of DATE2 if anyone wonders why drug abuse and violence are the overwhelming killers of the homeless, one reason is that the government is paying them to kill themselves and one another.

Deidentified_article_title: "Subsidizing Addiction"
Deidentified_paragraph_text: In [ORGANIZATION], the addiction program remained limited in scope. [ORGANIZATION], more at ease cutting checks for the elderly than administering a complicated welfare scheme, disfavored it. But a [LOCATION] congressional expansion of disability benefits, and some new [STREET] rulings, added more drug abusers to the caseload. Then, in [DATE], the federal government began spending tens of millions of dollars in outreach to get people on the disability rolls, focusing on the homeless, whose frequent addiction woes provided an easy route to benefits. Soon, 250,000 addicts were on the rolls.

Deidentified_article_title: "Subsidizing Addiction"
Deidentified_paragraph_text: One [STREET] that addicts have secured benefits is through new homelessness programs. The HEARTH Act, signed by President [PERSON] in [ORGANIZATION], reorganized homelessness spending to emphasize giving permanent homes to the chronically homelessthose on the streets for [LOCATION] and with a disability. This was known as the Housing First philosophy. Without any seeming debate, [ORGANIZATION] adopted the bureaucracys own definition of disability, which included substance use disorder.

Deidentified_article_title: "Subsidizing Addiction"
Deidentified_paragraph_text: [ORGANIZATION] told local governments to devise a single ranking to determine which homeless people get free or subsidized housing. Those with significant health or behavioral health challenges, such as substance use disorders, should get an advantage, [ORGANIZATION] said. In a new twist on the old disability programs, the federal government also began making criminality a favorable condition for benefits. One of its housing-voucher programs for the homeless, [ORGANIZATION] said, should prioritize those with criminal records and those with high utilization of crisis services, such as jails.

Deidentified_article_title: "Subsidizing Addiction"
Deidentified_paragraph_text: The [ORGANIZATION] mandates led a nonprofit group, [ORGANIZATION], to create the infelicitously named [ORGANIZATION], or [ORGANIZATION] pronounced vee-eye spi-dat, which local governments nationwide adopted. In a typical [ORGANIZATION] survey for single homeless adults, a homeless person can accumulate points toward free housing. He can get a point if he has run drugs for someone or shared a needle. He gets another point if his drug abuse got him evicted from an apartment. Theres another bonus point for taking medication other than the [STREET] the doctor prescribed, or selling the medication. For crime, the system awards a point if the homeless person has tried to harm someone in [ORGANIZATION], another for being the alleged perpetrator of a crime, and yet another for landing in a drunk tank, jail, or prison. If the person does enough drugs and commits enough crimes, he can get six total points.

Deidentified_article_title: "Subsidizing Addiction"
Deidentified_paragraph_text: Now, as a consequence, many states and cities provide their own scoring systems, often after adjusting the scoring to emphasize questions to which black people are, supposedly, more likely to answer yes. Under [ORGANIZATION], a homeless individual gets four points for agreeing that I am currently using alcohol or drugs and not in recovery but only one point if he has been in recovery for [ORGANIZATION] The individual gets an extra two points if he has had an overdose or alcohol poisoning in [LOCATION]. In [ORGANIZATION], [PERSON], the government says that the scoring system should focus on getting housing for those with active substance use, frequent criminal justice interactions, and, ideally, a felony. GPE2 asks if applicants have ever had to use violence to keep yourself safe answering affirmatively yields bonus points for a new house. In all these places, getting into recovery or refraining from violence is almost fatal for an applicants chances for housing and benefits.

Deidentified_article_title: "Subsidizing Addiction"
Deidentified_paragraph_text: The homeless can accelerate their benefits by committing new crimes. Many cities have created specialty courts to deal with the particular problems of the addicted, the mentally ill, and the homeless. While some of these institutions use the power of mandated treatment to change lives, others have become another means to distribute funds to criminals. See Keeping the Mentally Ill Out of Jail, [ORGANIZATION]. If youre homeless in [ORGANIZATION] and commit an offense such as trying to sell drugs, you will get assigned to the Downtown [ORGANIZATION] Community [STREET]. According to internal documents, your supposed punishment will be access to basic needs, social services, and other resources, so as to address the root causes of your situation.

Deidentified_paragraph_text: In [ORGANIZATION], similarly, the [ORGANIZATION] program will let anyone charged with crimes vaguely associated with homelessness, such as defecating in public, aggressive soliciting, drinking in public, fighting, or even plain destruction of property to receive, instead of punishment, supportive housing, case management, medical services, family amp employment programs, and meals service.

Deidentified_article_title: "Subsidizing Addiction"
Deidentified_paragraph_text: The governments effort to give housing priority to addicts and criminals is even more damaging because the current [ORGANIZATION] model discourages treatment for addiction or other problems. The idea behind [ORGANIZATION], also known as permanent supportive housing, was that homeless people needed low barriers to get off the [STREET] and into housing any mandates for treatment, on this view, would discourage homeless applicants.

Deidentified_article_title: "Subsidizing Addiction"
Deidentified_paragraph_text: [ORGANIZATION] is now official federal policy, and every local homelessness group receiving federal funds has to adopt it. [PERSON] tells these groups that mandates for addiction services should be rare and minimal if used at all. The head of a major nonprofit providing housing for Native Americans in [ORGANIZATION] told me that many of her homeless clients suffered severe alcohol problems, but the federal government upbraided her when she tried to require minimal treatment in exchange for housing. The [ORGANIZATION] homeless-services center warns that housing may not be restricted based on . . . current sobriety, willingness to participate in substance abuse treatment or counseling, or even goal setting of any sort.

Deidentified_article_title: "Subsidizing Addiction"
Deidentified_paragraph_text: Some [ORGANIZATION] programs dont just disdain treatment they actively encourage drug abuse. One [ORGANIZATION] program, [ORGANIZATION], for example, provides homeless addicts with free apartments fully furnished units chosen by the participantsas well as a needle exchange and necessary drug paraphernalia.

Deidentified_article_title: "Subsidizing Addiction"
Deidentified_paragraph_text: The only reasons the number of overdoses in [ORGANIZATION] housing is not higher is that, first, the city doesnt track all overdoses, and, second, it has installed hallway Narcan dispensers to help revive overdosed residents. The horrific results of these programs confirm recent studies that show that the homeless placed in supportive housing are more likely to abuse drugs and alcohol than those left on the streets. And these grim findings dovetail with decades worth of research showing that boosting income to addicts increases their drug consumption and the likelihood of relapse. A free house frees addicts from lots of other expenses.

Deidentified_article_title: "Subsidizing Addiction"
Deidentified_paragraph_text: The drug-abuse problem in these units has gotten so bad that the federal government awarded the largest homeless-housing provider, [ORGANIZATION], almost 4 million to research overdose prevention practices in permanent supportive housing. The outcome of the research, by the very definition of permanent supportive housing, cannot be to discourage drug abuse.

Deidentified_article_title: "Subsidizing Addiction"
Deidentified_paragraph_text: The federal [ORGANIZATION], [ORGANIZATION], a hotbed of activism, runs several programs designed to get benefits to addicts. One, ORG2 and Recovery, seeks to enroll individuals with substance use disorders for disability. Its literature trumpets the ways its disability applications get flagged by the bureaucracy for quicker and more positive treatment and reports that 71 percent of its applications are approvedtwice the rate of all applicants. Another [ORGANIZATION] program, [ORGANIZATION], tries to connect clients who experience substance use disorders, along with other mental-health problems, to everything from [LOCATION] to SSI to food stamps.

Deidentified_article_title: "Subsidizing Addiction"
Deidentified_paragraph_text: In line with the medicalization of every aspect of modern life, federal [ORGANIZATION] dollars for indigent health care are now used for housing the homeless, and specifically for drug addicts. [ORGANIZATION] and [PERSON] use [ORGANIZATION] funds to help those with both mental health and addiction disorders find a [STREET] to live and help them keep their current housing. [PERSON] says that its goal is to keep people with substance-abuse disorders in sustainable housing through improved supports. GPE2 says that its special [ORGANIZATION] program for the disabled provides housing support to those with alcohol abuse, cannabis abuse, cocaine abuse, hallucinogen abuse, opioid abuse and the all-encompassing other stimulant abuse, as long as these are accompanied by a drug-induced mood [PERSON] uses [ORGANIZATION] and other funds to support the most incorrigible addicts. A homeless drug abuser in GPE4 wont get special help if she overdosed only twice [ORGANIZATION] if she had three or more overdoses, she can get free transportation, childcare support, establishment of benefits, as well as assistance in receiving SSI, SSDI, [ORGANIZATION], [ORGANIZATION], and General [PERSON] funds.

Deidentified_article_title: "Subsidizing Addiction"
Deidentified_paragraph_text: These programs are in addition to the general cash provision for the homeless, which itself has deleterious consequences. Many cities like [ORGANIZATION] and [PERSON] phased out such cash programs [ORGANIZATION] the latter under then-mayor [ORGANIZATION] [ORGANIZATION] program, due to concerns about the money fueling alcohol and drug abuse, but theyve now come back into vogue. One old-school junkie told former GPE2 gubernatorial candidate PERSON1 about all the funds he gets to abuse drugs and live in GPE3 by the Bayover 600 in cash and 200 in food [DATE]. I get paid to be homeless in [PERSON].

Deidentified_article_title: "Subsidizing Addiction"
Deidentified_paragraph_text: But now, government programs hand out dozens of free needles to anyone who asks. Cities like [ORGANIZATION] and [PERSON] moved to providing free glass pipes for [LOCATION] or free foil and cookers for heroin, usually focused again on the homeless. The putative health benefits of new glass pipes and foil have never been clearly explained.

Deidentified_article_title: "Subsidizing Addiction"
Deidentified_paragraph_text: Some cities have found even more direct ways to subsidize addiction. [ORGANIZATION] famously provided alcohol, [PERSON], and cigarettes to homeless addicts when it put them in free hotel rooms during the FAC0 lockdowns. The city also laid out in the hotel lobbies the usual assortment of free needles, rubber tourniquets for injections, cookers for heroin, and glass pipes for methamphetamine and crack. The city said that these supplies were necessary to keep the homeless in the hotels and protect them from the effects of FAC0. And it worked [ORGANIZATION] did not see a single homeless death from FAC0 in the pandemics [ORGANIZATION]. Yet overall homeless deaths were double DATE1 in the citys history more than 80 percent were substance overdoses.

Deidentified_paragraph_text: More than 100,000 Americans overdosed [ORGANIZATION], the vast majority from opioids. More drug abuse has been accompanied by more violence and crime, as well as increases in homelessness, especially on the [STREET]. Many cities have seen a doubling in [LOCATION] homeless deaths just over DATE2. Earlier fears about heroin or the crack epidemic pale in comparison with the modern blight.

Deidentified_paragraph_text: In a better world, the government would help damaged individuals to move ahead with their lives. But [ORGANIZATION], as [ORGANIZATION] and other homeless people know, the government is helping them kill themselves on the public dime.

Deidentified_article_title: [ORGANIZATION] ends most single-family zoning
Deidentified_paragraph_text: The editorial board14 [ORGANIZATION]ns are fed up with problems not getting solved, and paying more for almost everything  from housing to gas to electricity. Deidentified_paragraph_text: That is what happened to us. Houseless Communities Revillaging The concept of village has a particular life in homeless communities throughout the [ORGANIZATION] When [ORGANIZATION], an urban planner, professional tiny house builder and author of the book [LOCATION], visited homeless encampments across the [ORGANIZATION] as a project for his masters thesis [ORGANIZATION], the medias portrayal of homeless encampments was one of dismal spaces rampant with drug abuse and crime. But what he actually encountered were uniquely supportive, democratic, often intricately organized and relatively nonviolent20 communities. PERSON1 now works as project director for [ORGANIZATION] in [ORGANIZATION], [ORGANIZATION], which has been a national model for low-income, tiny home villages since [LOCATION]. The organization works to establish both temporary, transitional villages for people who have been houseless, as well as permanent, affordable housing villages. Their permanent villages are set up in an alternative homeownership model that is a hybrid between a community land trust, where the organization owns the land, and limited equity co-ops that allow residents to co-own shares of the village and gain equity over time. The idea is to ensure living in these villages remains affordable for low-income people in perpetuity. PERSON2, ORG1 community relations director, says houseless communities offer a particularly potent example of how people naturally gravitate toward villages and interdependence in order to survive, which is why the majority of the rules, standards and operations of their villages are all independently run by residents. [ORGANIZATION] also sets itself up as a model for anyone interested in forming an affordable tiny house community.

During one brief moment, someone starts babbling, only to be told to be quiet by others. When I look back, I dont see any of the homeless people actively participating in the religious rites. After the service, I explore the rest of the church. Most of the wooden pews with no padding for comfort are occupied by a sleeping person. Three people are lying on the floor in the back. I speak briefly to [LOCATION], a new employee of [ORGANIZATION]. When I ask PERSON3 how the homeless can be helped and what should be done, he speaks of a lack of motivation, of people going down a path of not caring anymore instead of having a fire burning in you. PERSON3 talks about the need for a work ethic, and how its too simplistic to say the homeless problem is an effect of the citys expensive housing. But hes also adamant that people need help We just cant give up on the willing, he says. I ask him if the homeless people he encounters have loved ones or families who could help. PERSON3 says most of them are probably embarrassed to go home because you dont want to hear it from your family anymore after presumably failing in previous tries to get off the streets.6.

No doubt, mental health and addiction, perhaps both in many or most cases, make helping the homeless while respecting individual rights uniquely challenging. Deidentified_article_title: [ORGANIZATION] out-of-control homelessness crisis could be combated by a new tracking tool
Deidentified_paragraph_text: [ORGANIZATION] by [ORGANIZATION] [PERSON] new tracking system could soon identify thehistory and future needs of everyhomeless man, woman, and child in the city. The platform is a much-need solution to the citys outdated and inconsistent databases. Homeless tracking systems have showed promise in places like [PERSON], whichreduced its chronic homeless population by 91 in DATE1.Not too long ago, [PERSON] homeless tracking system consisted of a pile of papers in cardboard boxes.

Deidentified_article_title: [ORGANIZATION] out-of-control homelessness crisis could be combated by a new tracking tool
Deidentified_paragraph_text: Now, the city is launching a high-tech platform to identify every homeless resident and his or her level of need. The launch represents a growing effort, led by newly-elected [ORGANIZATION] PERSON0,to crack down on the citys visible homeless crisis. [ORGANIZATION] is one of the top-ranking1 cities for homelessness in the country, with an [ORGANIZATION] homeless population of 7,500. The new system intends to track thehealth, housing, jail, and counseling history of every homeless person in the city. Its a far cry from the old method, which spanned 15 different databases across multiple agencies. This allowed homeless residents to slip through the cracks, with people who might be registered in one system left out of others. The new solution known asONE System Online Navigation and Entry System aggregates this data into a singleplatform. As part of the test process, the city solicited feedback fromvolunteer consultants at [ORGANIZATION] and other tech companies. The final product allows homeless outreach professionals to log in to an app and view the state of homelessness in the city in real time. But first, it requiresindividuals to be registered at shelters or one of the citys two walk-in centers, which are run by [ORGANIZATION]. Upon registration, homeless residents are asked 17 questions that relate to their history of care and future needs. This helps determine which residents are in dire need of housing, and which can have their concerns met relatively quickly. By [ORGANIZATION], the database will have collected enough names to begin the housing placement process for individual residents. As of [LOCATION], the system has already begun to track homeless families throughout the city. According toJeff [PERSON], the head of the citys ORG2, the platform hasslashed wait times for families at local shelters from [ORGANIZATION] to [ORGANIZATION]. I know its going to make a difference, he told The [ORGANIZATION] Chronicle3.Maybe not right away, but it will happen. If the systems in other cities are any indication, [PERSON] could be right. In [PERSON], where a program recordsevery time a homeless person receives shelter, counseling, or another service, the city managed to reduce chronic homelessness4by 91 in [DATE]. Thats a big challenge for [ORGANIZATION], but one the city may now be more equipped to handle.

Though I recognize that some developers said that these affordable housing thresholds were financially unworkable in housing developments, this decision overtime will reduce the stock of affordable housing in [ORGANIZATION]. I believe the best [STREET] for the city to start improving the situation is to recommit to its own affordable housing ordinance. This will help expand the stock of affordable housing built in future development projects. As market-rate housing expands, so should the availability of affordable housing. The city should also encourage more developers to contribute to the housing trust fund. This would give the city resources to finance the building of additional affordable housing or to provide other kinds of support for those struggling to afford rising housing costs. At some points in the past developers have use the option of housing trust fund contributions to get out of obligations to build affordable housing units. To avoid this, the city should use this option in conjunction with the building of affordable housing units, along with making sure that developer contributions are fair for the community and have an actual impact addressing housing needs. PERSON1 The loss of redevelopment funding is regrettable, but affordable housing is continuing to be built across the state with other sources of funding and mechanisms. The end of redevelopment agencies has not been the end of affordable housing construction. The first step is to do an independent, in-depth study that looks at what level of inclusionary housing is actually achievable. We need a solid understanding of what can work so that the city is not relying on subjective claims by developers of what does or does not pencil out. The city needs an independent arbitrator of how affordable housing can be included so we can maximize affordable units in future projects. Secondly, I would like to look into restoring the suspended Middle Income Ordinance to provide affordable workforce housing.

Deidentified_paragraph_text: Beyond terminology, it is critical to understand that these words alone do not fully illustrate the suffering and instability caused by gentrification and displacement. Throughout this discussion we must also recognize that these patterns of homelessness, the shattering of communities and the loss of stability are not distributed proportionately across racial demographics, introducing a critical nuance that those who claim color blindness fail to recognize. Deidentified_paragraph_text: While [ORGANIZATION] alone cannot carry the blame for this crisis plaguing the region, [ORGANIZATION] has a direct, persistent hand in fueling its conditions. This creates an influx of people who compete for housing, pricing out low income residents simply trying to find a home within their own communities. We do this through the labor we contribute to [ORGANIZATION] through campus jobs or research, through our tuition dollars and the donations we bring in as inspirational stories pitched to donors. Deidentified_paragraph_text: The podcast is the culmination of [ORGANIZATION] of work by our organizations writers. Episode one, PERSON0 Sleepless on the Streets8, the first of two episodes out [LOCATION], takes us deep inside her experience of sleeplessness during the two [ORGANIZATION] she experienced homelessness, where trauma and sleep deprivation start to merge. Current Issue [PERSON]  In episode two, A Veteran Journalist [PERSON] [ORGANIZATION] [ORGANIZATION] host PERSON2 tells the shocking story of how his illustrious career in journalism fell apart in middle age. A former host of ORG1 Talk of the [ORGANIZATION] and chief national correspondent of [ORGANIZATION] discusses building his journalism career in predominantly white newsrooms and ultimately losing his job and health insurance, while facing down cancer and subsequent medical debt. Explaining the crisis facing older workers, he offers insights into how to fix this uniquely American condition. He also speaks to the impact of the ageism, racism, and paternalism built into the DNA of our newsrooms, along with the broader precariousness of the media industry. Future episodes will explore life on the front lines of the pandemic, the administrative burden of accessing social services, the crisis of affordable housing, and the faulty American concept of rugged individualism. Deidentified_paragraph_text: [ORGANIZATION] has carefully reviewed the eleven rules of [STREET] and eleven forms proposed to implement the newly enacted Community Assistance, Recovery, and [ORGANIZATION] and writes to respectfully oppose their content and the process and procedures created by them. The [ORGANIZATION] Act mandates that ORG1 adopt the rules and forms necessary to the [ORGANIZATION] [STREET] process and the promotion of state-wide consistency.2 However, the proposed rules and forms fail to remedy the coercion embedded in the system the [ORGANIZATION] Act created, that will, in practice, remove unhoused community members with perceived mental health conditions from the public eye without effectively addressing their mental health conditions or lack of housing.3 Indeed, the rules and forms proposed by the ORG2 raise new concerns around overbroad application, abuse, and accessibility.

Deidentified_article_title: World: Public Comment on Proposed Rules and Forms for CARE Act
Deidentified_paragraph_text: Rather than adopting these proposals and continuing along the path to coercion, we urge you to more deeply consult with disability, racial justice, housing, and peer-led groups to reach a more holistic, rights-respecting approach to address the lack of resources for autonomy-affirming treatment options and affordable housing.

Deidentified_article_title: World: Public Comment on Proposed Rules and Forms for CARE Act
Deidentified_paragraph_text: The proposed forms name the expansive categories of petitioners allowed by the [ORGANIZATION] Act including roommates, family members, first responders, police officers, homeless outreach workers, public guardians, conservators, service providers and the director of the county behavioral health agency.6 These groups have the power to thrust a person into the jurisdiction of the [ORGANIZATION] courts without the persons consent or knowledge, despite the fact that many petitioners may lack any expertise on identifying signs and symptoms of mental health conditions.

Deidentified_article_title: World: Public Comment on Proposed Rules and Forms for CARE Act
Deidentified_paragraph_text: Nor does this proposal address the possible impact of a threatened petition. Law enforcement and outreach workers may threaten unhoused people with referral to the [ORGANIZATION] [STREET] process created by the [ORGANIZATION] Act to pressure them to move from a given area. Even if these state actors do not then unilaterally funnel those who disobey their commands into the [ORGANIZATION] [STREET] process, the mere threat of a petition could traumatize and disrupt communities. Given the long history of law enforcement using its authority to [STREET] unhoused people from public spaces, it is dangerous to provide them with additional powers to do so.12

Deidentified_article_title: [ORGANIZATION] 's [ORGANIZATION]
Deidentified_paragraph_text: In his final speech from [ORGANIZATION] in [ORGANIZATION], President [PERSON] warned the nation that the military had joined with the arms industry and had acquired unwarranted influence over American politics. His term for this alliance was the military industrial complex.Since that time, PERSON1 term has been co-opted by other critics of special interests pooling their resources to exercise dangerous influence on [ORGANIZATION] democracy one example would be the so-called homeless industrial complex.

Deidentified_article_title: [ORGANIZATION] 's [ORGANIZATION]
Deidentified_paragraph_text: Its a social services-industrial complex, if you will, one that could prove even more difficult to subdue than its military counterpart. In [ORGANIZATION], writing for [PERSON], author [PERSON] asked Is There a Homeless Industrial Complex That Perpetuates Homelessness? And in [LOCATION], a former homeless activist published in the ultra-liberal [ORGANIZATION] an article entitled The Homeless Industrial Complex Problem. The alliance of special interests that constitutes what has now become [ORGANIZATION] are government bureaucracies, homeless advocacy groups operating through nonprofit entities, and large government contractors, especially construction companies and land development firms. Heres how the process works Developers accept public money to build projects to house the homeless - either bridge housing, or permanent supportive housing. Cities and counties collect building fees and hire bureaucrats for oversight.

Deidentified_article_title: [ORGANIZATION] 's [ORGANIZATION]
Deidentified_paragraph_text: Cities and counties create massive bureaucracies. The nonprofits dont just run these projects - the actual people staffing these shelters arent overpaid - they operate huge bureaucratic empires with overhead, marketing budgets, and executive salaries that do nothing for the homeless. None of these dynamics are terribly unique. Government funded programs are rarely considered bargains. And despite prodigious waste, [ORGANIZATION] military is nonetheless the most fearsome in the world. Similarly, despite mismanaging literally billions in proceeds from bonds and taxes collected to help the homeless, in absolute numbers [ORGANIZATION] population of homeless may have actually declined over [ORGANIZATION]. How Many Homeless Are There in America?This surprises a lot of people, but theres a lot more to that story. According to [ORGANIZATION], in [LOCATION] there were 647,000 homeless people in the [ORGANIZATION], but by the time the most recent count was released in [DATE], that number had declined to 543,000. Why, if so much money is being wasted, and the homeless crisis seems to be more acute than ever, are the absolute numbers of homeless actually falling? First of all, the numbers may be incorrect. These counts may be grossly understated. An illuminating critique of how ORG2s point-in-time homeless count may be understating the numbers was published by [ORGANIZATION] in [LOCATION]. Author PERSON0 participated in an official count, covering a section of [ORGANIZATION], [ORGANIZATION], in [TIME] of [DATE]. ORG2 requires cities and counties to complete the count, on [PERSON], [PERSON], in order to receive federal funding for homeless programs. But canvassing the streets of any city during the pre-dawn hours during [ORGANIZATION] is bound to miss a lot of people. Quoting from the article, The count is during [LOCATION] [TIME], when its harder to actually find folks because theyre seeking some sort of refuge. They want to stay out of sight in general for their own safety. Knowing just how many Americans are homeless is further complicated by competing definitions of homelessness. ORG3 [ORGANIZATION] claimed in a [ORGANIZATION] report that 1.3 million K-12 students were homeless in DATE9. But [ORGANIZATION] defines the homeless as not only those who are unsheltered or in homeless shelters, but those sharing housing due to loss of their own home, or living in hotels or motels. Even in [ORGANIZATION], a state where homelessness is now a crisis clbre for state legislators in [LOCATION], and a cautionary horror story for conservative critics of [ORGANIZATION] politics, at first glance, the overall numbers suggest the problem is overblown. On the map depicted below, using ORG2 data, the state by state homeless trend is shown for [DATE] from [LOCATION] to [LOCATION]3, in which [ORGANIZATION]s total homeless population actually dropped by 3.4 percent. But reports from around the state dispute the ORG2 assessment. According to a [LOCATION]1 article published in [ORGANIZATION], in GPE4, the number of homeless residents jumped 43 percent over [LOCATION]2. In [PERSON], that number was 42 percent. GPE6 volunteers surveying the regions homeless population found a 50 percent increase over [DATE]. GPE7 notched a 17 percent increase since [LOCATION]3. When [PERSON] officials released the results of their most recent count, homelessness was up by 12 percent over [LOCATION]4 in the county and up 16 percent in the City of [PERSON]. Nobody seems to know whether these flaws and ambiguities in how the homeless are counted mean that the crisis is in fact worse now than ever, despite official numbers showing a decline. But total numbers alone dont tell the whole story. How the homeless are treated, and where the homeless are concentrated, has changed a great deal in [LOCATION]5. This is the real reason the homeless crisis [LOCATION]6 is worse than ever. The next map, below, using data from [ORGANIZATION], shows [DATE] estimates of the total homeless population by state. In [PERSON], the cost for existing programs to help the homeless is approximately 100,000 per homeless person per year. Given the number of unsheltered homeless in [PERSON], this spending is totally ineffective. These costs are absurd. Designing solutions that cost less, but offer shelter to 100 percent of the homeless, is vastly preferable to solutions that cost so much that only a fraction of the homeless get assistance. Creative solutions exist that cost far less. Off the shelf tents, sheds, prefab tiny homes, and prefab homes made from shipping containers are all less costly options. Relocating the homeless to repurposed industrial or retail sites that are already built out and not on premium real estate would cut costs. Putting shelters in the middle of some of the most expensive real estate on earth not only squanders finite available funds, but when the unused property is government owned, the chance is lost to sell that property and invest the proceeds in less expensive locations.

Deidentified_article_title: Parking lots are the new solution to the homelessness crisis in cities  but they're also part of the problem
Deidentified_paragraph_text: Even in [ORGANIZATION], where safe parking is becoming more common, only 10 of the citys streets allow residents to lodge in their vehicle. These restrictions are often driven by concerns over homeless residents bringing crime, litter, or noise to a neighborhood. A better use of parking spacesTheres an irony to all of this controversy. Aside from their ability to safely shelter homeless residents, parking lots take up quite a bit of unnecessary space in cities. A recent study13from [ORGANIZATION] found that cities often have more parking spaces than their residents require. In certain parts of [ORGANIZATION], parking accounted for 40 of the land area, despite the fact that nearly half of all of households didnt own or operate a car. And in [ORGANIZATION], the city had enough parking space to give four spots to every household. This pattern is likely to grow worse as the share of drivers in GPE3 cities continues to decline. With many parking lots left unoccupied, these spaces could easily be converted into a more permanent solution for homeless residents affordable housing. The problem is that developers and landowners profit far more from parking structures than they do from affordable development. In many cases, developers are even required14 to install a certain number of parking spaces in residential or office buildings. This has the effect of driving up [LOCATION] in cities, making them less accommodating to low-income residents. As cities debate whether to expand or restrict their safe parking programs, they must confront an unfortunate paradox Parking lots might lessen the strain of homelessness in cities, but theyre also a big part of the problem. Deidentified_paragraph_text: The mobs capacity for nativist violence against migrants has also been increasingly evident in postcolonial settings, perhaps nowhere more than in [ORGANIZATION]. [ORGANIZATION], [ORGANIZATION] argues that the deep historical inequalities of racialized citizenship in [ORGANIZATION] remain spatially embedded in informal squatter settlements with long histories of popular resistance against apartheid, characterized by distinctive repertoires of collective action that continue to be mobilized in a still-unfinished history of struggle for race and class equality. This continuing struggle for equality and social justice on the parts of [ORGANIZATION]s Black poor  ostensible citizens  draws on shared experiences of everyday deprivations and collective labor, exacerbating the social distance between long-established local squatters and foreign newcomers whom they perceive to be politically indifferent or opportunistic. At times of protest, familiar practices of insurgent citizenship among the seasoned denizens of apartheid and its aftermaths have increasingly been diverted into mob violence against other Black African migrants. Thus, paradoxically, apparently [PERSON], while clearly plagued by nativism and anti-foreigner racism, may be seen nonetheless to articulate the frustrated claims for inclusion on the parts of structurally excluded ostensible citizens, rather than a purely exclusionary impulse on the part of those who are presumed to already belong.
